title: Circular Motion
content:
Circular motion
Understanding
➔ Period, frequency, angular displacement, and angular velocity
➔ Centripetal force
➔ Centripetal acceleration

Nature of science
The drive to develop ideas about circular motion came from observations of the universe.
How was it that astronomical objects could move in circular or elliptical orbits? What kept
them in place in their motion? Scientists were able to deduce that there must be a force acting
radially inwards for every case of circular motion that is observed. Whether it is a bicycle going
around a corner or a planet orbiting its star, the physics is the same.

Applications and skills
➔ Identifying the forces providing the centripetal forces such as tension, friction,
gravity, electrical, or magnetic
➔ Solving problems involving centripetal force, centripetal acceleration, period, frequency,
angular displacement, linear speed, and angular velocity
➔ Qualitatively and quantitatively describing examples of circular motion including
cases of vertical and horizontal circular motion

Equations
➔ speed–angular speed relationship: v = ωr
➔ centripetal acceleration: a = v² / r = 4π²r / T²
➔ centripetal force: F = mv² / r = mω²r

Moving in a circle
Most children take great delight in an object on a string whirling in a circle – though they may
be less happy with the consequences when the string breaks! Rides at a theme park and trains
on a railway are yet more examples of movement in a circle. What is needed to keep something
rotating at constant speed?

In circular motion we say that the speed is constant but not the velocity. Velocity, as a vector,
has both magnitude and direction. The object on the string has constant speed, but its direction
is changing all the time. Whenever velocity changes (even if only the direction), the object is
accelerated. Understanding this acceleration is key to understanding circular motion.

Angular displacement
The angle moved around the circle from the starting point is called the angular displacement.
It is measured in radians or degrees, but radians are preferred in physics. One full revolution
is 2π radians.

Angular speed
Angular speed (ω) is the rate of change of angular displacement:
ω = θ / t

The relationship between angular and linear speed is v = ωr.

Centripetal acceleration
An object moving at constant speed in a circle is continuously changing direction, so it must be
accelerating towards the center. The magnitude of this acceleration is:
a = v² / r = ω²r

Centripetal force
According to Newton’s second law, the force required to produce this acceleration is:
F = ma = mv² / r = mω²r

This inward force may be provided by tension, friction, gravity, or another interaction depending
on the system. For example, tension provides the centripetal force for a whirling mass on a
string, while gravity provides it for a planet orbiting a star.

every case of circular motion. Whether it is a bicycle going around a corner or a planet orbiting
its star, the physics is the same.

Applications and skills
➔ Identifying the forces providing the centripetal force such as tension, friction, gravity,
electrical, or magnetic
➔ Solving problems involving centripetal force, centripetal acceleration, period, frequency,

➔ Describing examples of circular motion including cases of vertical and horizontal motion

Equations
➔ Speed–angular speed relationship: v = ωr
➔ Centripetal acceleration: a = v² / r = 4π²r / T²
➔ Centripetal force: F = mv² / r = mω²r

Moving in a circle
Most children take delight in an object on a string whirling in a circle – though they may be
less happy when it breaks! Rides at theme parks and trains on curved tracks are examples of
circular motion. What keeps them rotating at constant speed?

In circular motion, the speed is constant but the velocity is not. Velocity has both magnitude
and direction; the direction changes continuously, meaning the object accelerates toward the
center. This inward acceleration is called the centripetal acceleration.

Angular displacement
The angle an object moves through around a circle from its starting point is its angular
displacement. It is usually measured in radians. One full revolution equals 2π radians.

Angular speed
Angular speed (ω) is the rate of change of angular displacement:
ω = θ / t

The link between angular and linear speed is given by:
v = ωr

Period and frequency
The period (T) is the time for one complete revolution. The frequency (f) is the number of
revolutions per second. Their relationship is:
T = 1 / f and ω = 2πf

Centripetal acceleration
An object moving at constant speed in a circle is continuously changing direction, so it must be
accelerating toward the center. The magnitude of the acceleration is:
a = v² / r = ω²r

Centripetal force
According to Newton’s second law, the inward force needed to produce this acceleration is:
F = ma = mv² / r = mω²r

This centripetal force may be provided by tension, friction, gravity, or other forces depending
on the system. For instance, tension provides the force in a whirling mass on a string, while
gravity provides it for a planet orbiting a star.

Nature of science
Centripetal versus centrifugal
In everyday speech we hear of 'centrifugal force'—a fictitious outward force felt in a rotating
frame of reference. Physically, the real force is centripetal, directed toward the center. The
sensation of being flung outward arises because your body tends to move in a straight line
(Newton’s first law) while the rotating frame changes direction.

Examples and applications

Turning on a horizontal road
For a car rounding a bend, the friction between the tires and the road provides the centripetal
force. The condition for no skidding is:
(mv² / r) < μₛmg
which gives the maximum safe speed:
vₘₐₓ = √(μₛgr)

Banking
Tracks and roads are often banked to reduce reliance on friction. For a banked turn at angle θ,
the horizontal component of the normal force provides the centripetal force:
N sinθ = mv² / r
and the vertical component balances weight:
N cosθ = mg
Dividing gives:
tanθ = v² / (gr)
Thus, at a given speed and radius, the required banking angle is independent of mass.

Vertical circular motion
If an object moves in a vertical circle, the tension in the string changes with position.
At the top of the circle:
T_top + mg = mv² / r → T_top = mv² / r - mg
At the bottom of the circle:
T_bottom - mg = mv² / r → T_bottom = mv² / r + mg

The tension is maximum at the bottom and minimum at the top. To keep the motion circular,
the string must stay taut, requiring a minimum speed at the top:
v_top = √(gr)

Energy changes in a vertical circle
Neglecting air resistance, mechanical energy is conserved. As the object rises, kinetic energy
is converted into gravitational potential energy; as it descends, the reverse occurs. The speed
is greatest at the bottom and least at the top.

Example: car over a bridge
A car passes over a convex bridge of radius r. The normal reaction between car and road
provides the 'tension' of the circular motion. The car just loses contact when the normal force
is zero, so:
mg = mv² / r → v = √(gr)

Amusement rides
In rotating 'wall of death' rides, people are pressed against the wall as the floor drops away.
The normal reaction from the wall provides the centripetal force, and friction prevents them
from sliding down. When frictional force equals weight, μN = mg, allowing calculation of the
minimum rotation speed.

Worked example
A hammer thrower swings a 4.0 kg hammer on a 4.2 m chain 7.5 times in 5.2 seconds.
Find the angular speed and tension in the chain.

Number of revolutions = 7.5 → angular displacement = 7.5 × 2π = 15π radians
Angular speed = θ / t = 15π / 5.2 = 9.1 rad s⁻¹
Tension = m r ω² = 4.0 × 4.2 × (9.1)² = 1400 N

In reality, the thrower inclines the circle at about 45° to maximize range, so the actual tension
is slightly higher because a component of the tension must balance the hammer’s weight.
